The only reason for the delay in complet-hading these Inquiries was that he/felt it necessaryto postpone final Conclusions until the return ofthe Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs fromhis travels.Several members of the Cabinet expressed theview that they could not form any opinion on thesequestions until fuller material was available tothem.The Prime Minister assured his colleagues thatthere had never been any intention to take hurrieddecisions. The Cabinet had before them a Memorandum,circulated as a matter of urgency on the previous evening by the President of the Board of Education,on the subject of the feeding of school children in distressed areas (Paper C.P.-388 (28)).In this Memorandum Lord Eustace Percy suggestedthat any programme of Government assistance todistressed areas which may be announced before christmas should include a special provision forthe feeding of school children in those areas, andparticularly in Durham where there is grave cause for anxiety. His suggestion was to make a specialgrant to certain of the distressed areas whichwill relieve the rates of practically the whole ofthe cost of feeding, the grants to be given on conditions which would ensure proper administration under medical inspection. He proposed, therefore,that as an alternative to the existing percentagewe should offer a capitation grant equivalent to3d. per day per child fed, as a temporary arrange-ment continuing until next October.The Minister of Health informed his colleagues that the preliminary and provisional report of theOfficer of his Ministry who had visited SouthWales a report which was still subject to the remarks of the Medical Officer who had accompaniedhim indicated that he had discovered no case ofapparent sickness or ill-health due to under-feeding. Women were suffering most and were found to require^longer period for recovery afterchildbirth, and there was an increase in ricketsamong the children, - a disease due not toinsufficiency but to the wrong kind of food. 990t*S Kj iyjThe people were living to a great extent uponbread and margarine, which was not a proper diet.In spite of the rather unexpectedly favourablesymptom he had mentioned, Mr Neville Chamberlainregarded the position as serious and liable tobecome perilous at short notice. Although not ina position to make final recommendations, his mind was worIcing towards a system of communal feedingapplicable both to adults and children, similar tothat which had been put in force during the GoalStrike. The question of clothing was being dealtwith by the Lord MayorTs Fund, but it might bedesirable to supplement the Fund. If this were done at all it should be done soon, and should notbe on a paltry scale. Mr Chamberlain regarded itas a matter of great importance to avoid any actionwhich would result in a setback to the generalpolicy of transfer to other areas where men couldearn their livelihood. He also considered it important to harden the muscles and to employ the minds of the unemployed workers in order to fitthem for employment elsewhere.In the course of the discussion the cabinet were informed that the Lord Mayor's Fund at presentamounted to 135,000, but the result of centralisingthe efforts of the different localities was that very wide demands were being made on the Fund at thepresent time from all quarters which had subscribedthere to .Proposals were made, first, that greaterpublicity should be given to a letter written bythe Queen on the subject, and, later on, that theLord Mayor's Fund should be converted into aPrince of Wales' Fund, which, it was thought, 9 9 9(C- i.j tJwould result in the raising of a much larger sum.The Prime Minister undertook to consider this proposal.The Cabinet were also informed that theMinistry of Labour were carrying out the transferpolicy at the rate of from 1,000 to 1,100 adultsper week. It was suggested that-any availablefunds could not be better employed than in movingmarried men, with their families, as part of thispolicy. The Ministry of Labour were already atwork in regard to the Minister of Health's pro-posal for hardening up men for transfer. Inaddition, suggestions were made that the best formof assistance in the districts was to prepare men for emigration as agricultural labourers, but theCabinet were informed that it was extremelydifficult to provide facilities of this kind inthose particular districts.As regards Scotland the Cabinet were informedthat according to the latest reports there was nodestitution, but a good deal of hardship. TheEducation Authorities were providing boots andshoes for children in that part of the country.It was urged that any assistance given by theGovernment should be administered through theexisting authorities .The Chancellor of the Exchequer emphasizedthat the revenue prospects did not encourage himto think that there would be any surplus ofrevenue over expenditure, and that if any consider-able additional expenditure were incurred theBudget would not balance. He criticised some ofthe proposals from the financial point of view,and pointed out that in the aggregate they would require some 600,000 to 700,000.The Cabinet agreed (a) That a Committee, composed In his Memorandum Sir austen chamberlain urged that the American request couldnot be refused without giving gross offence andneedlessly embittering our relations.A short discussion revealed that the proposedMemorial did not commend itself favourably to theCabinet, and suggestions were made that possibly the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs mightbe willing to discuss it with the american ambassador.
